page.title: Nominal Phrases - Possessors
page.introduction:
The next type of modifier to consider is possessors. Possession can normally be expressed by a possessive pronoun (to be addressed in
Pronouns) or by a full nominal phrase. Many languages also add some kind of marking, such as the 's in English, as an indication of possession. These markings are either affixes (or clitics) on the head noun or phrase-level clitics which attach to one end of the whole phrase. The English marking is this second type, because alongside phrases where the 's appears to attach to the head noun, as in the boy's mother, there are phrases which clearly show that the clitic attaches to the end of the whole nominal phrase, such as the boy that I just talked to's mother or the girl in green's wonderful speech.

form.instruction:
Think about how possession is expressed in your language. We won't be able to handle pre/post-positional phrases until
Pre/Post-positional Phrases and relative clauses within nominal phrases until
Relative Clauses, but examples such as the English ones above will clarify for you what type of possessive marking you have.
Note also that possessors can be embedded in one another, as in the boy's sister's dog. Include such an example in your test data.

radioGroup.prompt: Based on your examples, does your language have any special marking to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, there is no special marking
Yes, the head noun within the possessor is syntactically marked via an affix
Yes, the whole possessive phrase is syntactically marked via a phrasal clitic

radioGroup.prompt: Is the phrasal clitic written as a separate word?
radioGroup.radio: No, like in English, it attaches to the closest word

radioGroup.prompt: How does the clitic attach to the peripheral word of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: As a suffix, like in English
As a prefix
Yes

radioGroup.prompt: Is this possessive marker required on all possessors (other than pronouns)?
radioGroup.radio: No, it is optional in some cases
Yes, it is always required

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the possessive marker occur with respect to the possessor?
radioGroup.radio: Before the possessor
After the possessor

radioGroup.prompt: Based on your examples above, where does the possessor occur with respect to the noun being possessed?
radioGroup.radio: Before the noun
After the noun
On either side of the noun

form.introduction: We also need to know whether possessors and articles or demonstratives can co-occur in the same nominal phrase. In English, these elements do not co-occur, unless the possessor is expressed in a prepositional phrase. For example, we can't say those [the boy's] books; instead we use those books [of his] to express the same thought. Some other languages allow both possessors and articles or demonstratives to occur in the same phrase, so the first example above would be grammatical.

radioGroup.prompt: Can possessors co-occur with articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives in your language?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, they may co-occur
No, it is the same as English in this regard

radioGroup.prompt: Which case is used to mark the possessors in your language?
radioGroup.radio: Ergative, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs
Absolutive, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs
Genitive, a distinct marking for possessors

form.introduction: In some languages, in a possessed noun phrase the head noun and any modifiers matches the case of the possessor. In other languages, the possessor is marked with its own case, say genitive, while the head noun is marked with case depending on its position relative to the verb: nominative or accusative, ergative or absolutive depending on the case system.

radioGroup.prompt: Does the presence of a possessor change the case marking on the head noun to match the case of the possessor?
radioGroup.radio: No, the grammatical function of the head noun relative to the verb determines its case, not the presence of a possessor
Yes, the case of the head noun matches the case of the possessor, when a possessor is present
